There are so many other games I would rather have seen ported to Steam than Overwatch 2. Overwatch used to be such a fun game until it got turned into a tasteless cash grab by Blizzard. The only thing this version of Overwatch added was aggressive monetization and false promises. I'm glad to see more games porting to Steam though but I think that Blizzard sadly only did this out of greed rather than attempting to appeal to their fans.

안녕하세요, 저는 게임 리뷰어입니다. 오늘은 오버워치 2에 대해 부정적인 한국어 리뷰를 작성하려고 합니다.

오버워치 2는 이전 버전인 오버워치와 비교했을 때 큰 실망을 안겨주었습니다. 첫 번째로, 게임 플레이가 너무 단순하고 반복적입니다. 이전에는 다양한 영웅들과 그들의 고유한 능력을 활용하여 전략적인 게임 플레이를 즐길 수 있었습니다. 하지만 오버워치 2에서는 새로운 영웅들과 능력이 거의 없으며, 게임 플레이는 단조롭고 지루합니다.

두 번째로, 오버워치 2의 그래픽과 디자인도 실망스럽습니다. 이전 버전에서는 화려하고 생동감 있는 그래픽으로 플레이어들을 매료시켰습니다. 하지만 오버워치 2에서는 그래픽이 더욱 어둡고 흐릿하며, 영웅들의 디자인도 이전보다 덜 매력적입니다. 또한, 맵 디자인도 이전에 비해 훨씬 단조롭고 반복적입니다.

마지막으로, 오버워치 2의 커뮤니티와 개발자들의 응답에 대해서도 실망스럽습니다. 오버워치 2는 이전 버전과 비교하여 커뮤니티와 개발자들 간의 소통이 많이 줄어들었습니다. 이전에는 개발자들이 플레이어들의 피드백을 귀담아 듣고 게임을 개선하기 위해 노력했지만, 오버워치 2에서는 이러한 노력이 미미해졌습니다. 또한, 개발자들의 업데이트 속도도 느려져서 플레이어들의 기대에 부응하지 못하고 있습니다.

이러한 이유로 오버워치 2는 이전 버전에 비해 큰 실망을 안겨주었습니다. 게임 플레이의 단순함과 지루함, 그래픽과 디자인의 실망스러움, 그리고 커뮤니티와 개발자들의 소통 부족은 플레이어들에게 큰 실망을 안겨주고 있습니다. 따라서 오버워치 2를 추천하지 않습니다.

Overwatch 2? More like Over-hyped 2! Seriously, it's like a Hollywood blockbuster that never lived up to the trailers. You've got these "new and improved" heroes, but honestly, they're as refreshing as warm soda. Now, Team Fortress 2 – that's the real deal. It's like sipping on grandma's secret recipe lemonade on a hot summer day. It's got that vintage flavor, unique classes, and maps that are more memorable than your first crush. If you're looking for real fun, don't waste time with Overwatch 2's fancy fireworks. Grab a rocket launcher in TF2 and blow up your worries! 💥🎮

Team Fortress 2 is a 2007 multiplayer first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve Corporation. It is the sequel to the 1996 Team Fortress mod for Quake and its 1999 remake, Team Fortress Classic. The game was released in October 2007 as part of The Orange Box for Windows and the Xbox 360, and ported to the PlayStation 3 in December 2007.[1][2] It was released as a standalone game for Windows in April 2008, and updated to support Mac OS X in June 2010 and Linux in February 2013. It is distributed online through Valve's digital retailer Steam, with Electronic Arts managing retail and console editions.

Players join one of two teams—RED or BLU—and choose one of nine character classes to play as, with game modes including capture the flag and king of the hill. Development was led by John Cook and Robin Walker, the developers of the original Team Fortress mod. Team Fortress 2 was announced in 1998 under the name Team Fortress 2: Brotherhood of Arms. Initially, the game had more realistic, militaristic visuals and gameplay, but this changed over the protracted nine years of development. After Valve released no information for six years, Team Fortress 2 regularly featured in Wired News' annual vaporware list among other entries. Finally released on the Source game engine in 2007, Team Fortress 2 would preserve much of the core class-based gameplay of its predecessors while featuring an overhauled, cartoon-like visual style influenced by the works of J. C. Leyendecker, Dean Cornwell, and Norman Rockwell, alongside an increased focus on the visual and verbal characterization of its playable classes and what the developers have described as a 1960s spy movie aesthetic.

Team Fortress 2 has received critical acclaim for its art direction, gameplay, humor, and use of character in a wholly multiplayer game,[3][4][5][6] and since its release has been referred to as one of the greatest video games ever created.[7][8][9] The game continues to receive official Valve server support as of July 2023,[10] in addition to new content being released on a seasonal basis in the form of submissions made through the Steam Workshop. In June 2011, the game became free-to-play, supported by microtransactions for in-game cosmetics. A 'drop system' was also added and refined, allowing free-to-play users to periodically receive in-game equipment and items. Though the game has had an unofficial competitive scene since its release, both support for official competitive play through ranked matchmaking and an overhauled casual experience were added in July 2016.[11]

I've played the game before since OW back years ago. I still find OW2 fun and I think the decision to add the game to Steam was a good decision, but they took a lot of bad decisions along the way and I still find that OW1 was much more fun compared to OW2, which is insane considering that it actually has had new content constantly... It's just not interesting new content. That plus the old lootbox system is missed. It went from being one of the healthiest lootbox/skin systems to ever exist back in Overwatch 1 to one of the worst and most boring, it feels little rewarding at all. If you play this game, play it with friends (only sometimes), in its current state, it's probably the only way that the game is fun. This review may change in the future even further based on what Blizzard decides to do.

Despite the hateboner the whole internet seems to have for this game, its a pretty solid game. Sure, there are no lootboxes you can earn to get free cosmetics now and instead it has a shop and a battlepass. But that's the cosmetics, not the actual playable content.
Everything gameplay related is either unlockable by playing or directly free. And its not like if Overwatch was the one who invented this, every single free to play game does this. 
Seriously, if this game has caught your eye and you think it might be your thing, give it a try, dont let the internet ruin it for you.

This game is pay to win. You can either pay 10 dollars to unlock the new hero, or grind until level 45 in the battle pass.

If they removed that, the game would be a 6/10. However, with this pay-to-win element, the game is a 0/10. The game is also terribly balanced, Open Queue is really unfun and role queue isn't fun either because I may want to switch roles mid-game. 6v6 was more fun than 5v5 because it translated to less individual responsibility.
Blizzard revolutionised the concept of sequels by giving you the first game but with a bit less content.

[h1] Great Game, Terrible Management [/h1]
I'd like to state before I give this review that I am not negatively reviewing this game for the sake of review bombing. I'm not some butt-hurt TF2 fan who wants to watch this game die. While TF2 is my most played game and I would consider it my favorite game, for a long time Overwatch was my most played and favorite game. Some of my best gaming memories come from Overwatch. Everything negative I say in this review is out of disappointment in watching one of my favorite games dig its own grave. With all that out of the way, here are my thoughts on Overwatch 2.
[h1] The Positive [/h1]
Despite the negative review, I still really enjoy Overwatch. The core gameplay  is some of the most refined in the sub-genre of hero shooters. I think the switch from 6v6 to 5v5 is a very good decision because it keeps gameplay flowing with one less tank to lock down chokes. If you're here for just the gameplay and don't plan on spending any money, I would highly recommend this game.
[h1] The Negative [/h1]
Remember just a few seconds ago when I said I'd recommend this game to people who just care about gameplay and don't want to spend money? Well I sort of lied. You [b] can [/b] enjoy the gameplay without spending any money, if you're okay with grinding for hours to unlock all the heroes. Never owned Overwatch 1? You have to complete challenges to unlock all the Overwatch 1 heroes with the exception of a few that you start with. A new hero comes out? Have fun grinding to a ridiculous level on the battle pass to unlock them. Conversely, you could just buy the complete hero collection as well as battle pass tiers to instantly unlock all the heroes. It's incredibly frustrating to not have certain heroes because you just don't play very often and/or you didn't spend the money to unlock the heroes, especially since Overwatch character matchups work in a rock, paper, scissors style so not having a hero that counters an enemy's hero could cost your team the entire match, all because you didn't want to spend money. Some people may argue that since Overwatch 2 is Free to Play, it's fine that heroes cost money. However skins already exist to generate revenue for Overwatch 2, so gameplay doesn't have to be sacrificed for the sake of profit. Speaking of the monetization system, it's not very good. Instead of loot boxes, we have a battle pass. Battle passes are terrible, you pay for the battle pass probably only wanting one skin from it anyways, and you still have to grind the battle pass to get the skin. I never thought I would miss [b] loot boxes [/b], yet here we are. You can also buy the skins you want directly, if the skins you want are currently in the store, for $20 USD. The monetization is very greedy and entirely the fault of Blizzard. Speaking of things being Blizzards fault, the PvE mode that justified this sequel's existence is being cancelled, likely so Blizzard can move the hard working and talented development team away from the game they want and towards making a game that makes heaps of money at the expense of the players.
[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
If you're a fan of Overwatch 1 or looking for a good hero shooter, I give this game nothing but recommendation. It's still one of the best hero shooters ever made. Just don't spend any money on this game, because underneath this amazing shooter, lies a seedy underbelly of corporate greed. 

If you have any constructive criticism, counterarguments, or general comments feel free to leave a comment. I am open to and hopeful for insightful discussion. I'm not a professional reviewer so I'm sorry if my review is a little hard to understand or read.

This game and it's history is a prime example of what inevitably happens when the people hovering over you are paranoid, fearful, shallow, uninspired, and greedy.
